isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Service (1995 through 1999) - SECTION 6: CONNECTING RODS, PISTONS, RINGS AND SLEEVES - CONNECTING RODS

step1.para: Visually inspect the connecting rod bolts for nicks or damage.
Visually inspect the rod and cap mating surfaces for fretting. Replace as required.
Inspect the connecting rod piston pin bushing for wear as follows:

note.para: WHEN LUBRICATED WITH CLEAN ENGINE OIL, THE BOLTS MUST SCREW INTO THE ROD BY HAND. IF RESISTANCE IS MET, CLEAN THE ROD THREADS AND TRY A NEW BOLT. IF A NEW BOLT DOES NOT SCREW IN FREELY, THE ROD MUST BE DISCARDED. ROD THREADS CANNOT BE RETAPPED.

step2.para:
Using a telescoping gauge ( OEM1022) and an outside micrometer, measure the pin bore at two (2) locations 90° from one another and record the readings. Refer to Figure 6.16
.
Refer to "SPECIFICATIONS". If piston pin bushing I.D. exceeds minimum specification, it is worn and must be replaced.

figure.caption: Figure 6.16 Measuring Connecting Rod Piston Pin Bore

step1.para: Remove any worn bushing using a press and a driver.

Clean the connecting rod piston pin bushing bore throughly and visually inspect for defects. Using a telescoping gauge and a micrometer, measure the connecting rod piston pin bushing bore diameter at two (2) locations. If out of specifications, replace the connecting rod.
Check connecting rod bearing bore for "out-of-round" as follows:

step2.para: Lubricate connecting rod bolts with clean engine oil and assemble the cap to rod with out bearing insert. Tighten bolts to the special torque value.

Use an inside micrometer and measure connecting rod in three locations as shown in Figure 6.17
.
If the difference between point "B" and average of points "A" and "C" ([A+C] ÷ 2), exceeds "SPECIFICATIONS" rod must be replaced.

figure.caption: Figure 6.17 Checking Connecting Rod For Out-Of -Round

step1.para:
Measure connecting rod bearing bore taper ( Figure 6.18
), by measuring bore I.D. on each side of bearing bore. Record the readings. The difference between the two readings is the bore taper (See "SPECIFICATIONS"). Replace rod as required.
With connecting rod cap removed, visually inspect surface finish of connecting rod bearing bore. The bore must be smooth and free of scoring, nicks or burrs. Replace as required.
CONNECTING ROD BEND AND TWIST: Often engine component wear patterns can be identified and used to diagnose a problem. Some common examples of connecting rod wear patterns include:

step2.para: A shiny surface on edge of piston pin bushing usually indicates that a connecting rod is bent or piston pin hole is not in proper relation to piston skirt and ring grooves.
Abnormal connecting rod bearing wear can be caused by either a bent connecting rod or a tapered connecting rod bore.

Twisted connecting rods will not create an easily identifiable wear pattern but badly twisted rods will disturb action of entire piston, rings and connecting rod assembly and may be the cause of excessive oil consumption.

If any of these conditions exist, check the connecting rods for bends or twists using a suitable alignment fixture. Follow the instructions of the fixture manufacturer. If bend or twist exceeds "SPECIFICATIONS", replace the connecting rod.

note.para: IF THE CONNECTING RODS DO NOT MEET THE REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN "CONNECTING ROD INSPECTION", PARAGRAPHS 1-9. REPLACE THE ENTIRE CONNECTING ROD ASSEMBLY.
